item.title: Coronavirus: £3bn for NHS to prepare for possible second wave
item.description: The funding for England will also help ease winter pressures on the health service, No 10 says.

item.title: British Airways retires entire 747 fleet after travel downturn
item.description: British Airways is permanently grounding its jumbo jets which are nicknamed "the queen of the skies".

item.title: New South Wales erosion: Huge swells leave homes at risk of collapse
item.description: Huge waves have lashed the New South Wales coastline this week, causing erosion beneath homes.

item.title: Coronavirus: NHS to get extra £3bn and BA's 747s reach end of runway
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this Friday morning.

item.title: Hospital wedding for terminally ill patient
item.description: When Tash Young was given weeks to live, she was determined to marry her boyfriend before she died.

item.title: Coronavirus: UN makes record $10.3bn appeal for pandemic fight
item.description: The UN says up to 265 million people could face starvation because of the impact of Covid-19.

item.title: Blackpool Central Pier fire: Blaze breaks out during the night
item.description: Fire crews called to the scene found a workshop and ride well alight at about 03:00 BST.

item.title: Cédric Chouviat: French police charged over death of delivery driver
item.description: Cédric Chouviat, 42, shouted "I'm suffocating" seven times as officers put him in a chokehold.

item.title: Coronavirus: Spain orders culling of almost 100,000 mink
item.description: A minister says the cull in Aragon province was ordered "to avoid the risk of human transmission".

item.title: Poorest 'will pay price' of aid department merger - MPs
item.description: The Department for International Development is due to be combined with the Foreign Office.

item.title: Dambusters dog: Headstone replaced to remove racist name
item.description: A headstone honouring 617 Squadron's mascot - a black Labrador - is replaced at RAF Scampton.

item.title: The Papers: Russian hackers and the 'jihadi bride' returns
item.description: UK accusations that Russian hackers have targeted Covid-19 vaccine research dominate the front pages.

item.title: The bilbies 'thriving' after a 100-year absence in New South Wales
item.description: The marsupial has bred in the wild in New South Wales for the first time in a century.

item.title: Quiz of the week: Which Chicken Run star was 'plucked and stuffed'?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Dear customers, I face ruin, please come back'
item.description: Rumit Shah, who runs a chain of greeting cards shops, explains why empty city streets are ruining his business.

item.title: The Simpsons: The black actor hoping his impressions get him a job
item.description: Jayden Libran has had loads of support on Simpsons fan sites - but is it enough to get him a job?

item.title: Solar Orbiter: Closest ever pictures taken of the Sun
item.description: The European Solar Orbiter probe captures images just 77 million km from the Sun's surface.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'My once-in-lifetime holiday hasn't been refunded'
item.description: A couple tell of their holiday refund "panic" as consumer group Which? calls for action from regulators.

item.title: Spanish king leads memorial to victims of Covid-19
item.description: Tributes were paid to the victims of the pandemic outside the Royal Palace in Madrid.

item.title: Echoes of Empire: Aboriginal Australians and the legacy of colonialism
item.description: The BBC's Shaimaa Khalil explores how the life chances of indigenous Australians are rooted in colonialism.

item.title: In pictures: How coronavirus swept through Brazil
item.description: As the country passes 2m cases, we tell the story of how the outbreak spread in pictures.

item.title: Doctor Room: The counsellor helping digital sex crime victims
item.description: "I felt that taking a break is a sin," she says. "If I sleep it means more videos get out there."

item.title: Coronavirus: Sheep wool 'barely worth selling any more'
item.description: Coronavirus has meant a "terrible year" for British wool farmers, with fleeces now almost worthless.

item.title: The Benjamin Netanyahu Twitter hack that never was
item.description: Politicians and celebrities have had their accounts hijacked but not, apparently, Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Alan Rusbridger: Facebook oversight board must avoid 'half-baked judgements'
item.description: Alan Rusbridger, a member of the oversight board, acknowledged a desire to launch ahead of US vote.

item.title: Ellie Goulding: 'I'd just become a robot'
item.description: The star explains why she almost quit music, and how she found her way back after five years off.

item.title: What sort of future does the conference industry have?
item.description: Running conferences was a giant business before Covid-19, now the industry is looking for a new direction.

item.title: Who is Shamima Begum and how do you lose your UK citizenship?
item.description: Ms Begum travelled to Syria to join the so-called Islamic State group in 2015.

item.title: Archer breach could have ended up costing ECB 'tens of millions of pounds' - Giles
item.description: Jofra Archer's breach of bio-secure protocols could have been a "disaster" for England's summer, says director of cricket Ashley Giles.

item.title: 'These are the games that matter' - Solskjaer eyes top four after Man Utd beat Palace
item.description: Marcus Rashford and Anthony Martial score as Manchester United beat Crystal Palace to stay on course for a top-four finish.

item.title: PDAs and an 'unbelievable' interview - London 2012 things you may have forgotten
item.description: The Kenny kiss, going mad for Mo Farah and Bert le Clos' 'beautiful boy' - 10 moments you might have forgotten from the London 2012 Olympics.

item.title: Tom Bosworth: 'We must challenge online abuse'
item.description: Racewalker Tom Bosworth, the only openly gay man on the current British team, says that online abuse will 'grow and grow' unless it is called out and confronted.

item.title: McIlroy and Woods make solid starts at Memorial as Finau leads
item.description: World number one Rory Mcilroy and Tiger Woods make solid starts to the Memorial Tournament as Tony Finau sets the early pace in Ohio.

item.title: Olympics Rewind: The moment the London 2012 flame was lit
item.description: BBC Sport looks back to the moment the Olympic flame was lit during the opening ceremony for the London 2012 Games.

item.title: Coronavirus: How the financial shockwave is affecting jobs and money
item.description: With the UK facing a severe economic downturn, what is the outlook for our personal finances?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can my boss force me to go back to work?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people are starting to go back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: England will follow Scotland by making face coverings compulsory in shops.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The number of people claiming benefits has surged, but the unemployment rate has barely moved. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I now go on holiday in the UK?
item.description: Where can I go and what can do on a holiday in the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People at risk of becoming severely ill if they get coronavirus should take extra precautions.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Who won't have to wear face coverings in shops?
item.description: Questions about the face covering rule changes in England and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does lockdown work in Leicester and on a Herefordshire farm?
item.description: Local lockdowns are in force on a Herefordshire farm and in Leicester, but how do they work?

item.title: Letters of love: 'Our father wrote every day as he waited to be sent to Auschwitz'
item.description: Daniele Israel's daily letters to his family from jail in Trieste paint a moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.
